WRONG about 1965's "Battle of the Bulge", which is criticizes for using 
"modern tanks" and filming in "temperate" Spain. FIRST, there just were 
hardly any US Shermans and certainly NO German Tigers or Panzers of any 
sort operational then, unlike now. The M-24 light tanks they used as 
Shermans WERE WW2 light tanks introduced at the end of the war. The mid 50s 
vintage M-47s playing the Tigers looked nothing like them, but they were 
already long replaced by M-60s and M-48s in the US Army. Spain was used 
since they had the tanks and an Army available, and was commonly used for 
WW2 films. Was kinda hard to imitate the overcast conditions during the 
Bulge, but the terrain was very passable. The film noted that it was a bit 
simplified to capture the spirit of the battle, compressing some events, 
and barely mentioning Bastogne. Was still a great movie. "Band of Brothers" 
gave a more accurate but far more restricted view of the B of the Bulge. ﻿

Oh, I forgot to mention that the size ratio of the M-24s compared to the 
M-47s was equal to that between the Sherman and the Tiger, though they were 
actually bigger than the M-24/47s. It's still a very good movie.

You need to go back to your research, old boy. It doesn't seem to have 
done  you much good so far. There were indeed free blacks in SC, as well as 
other places in the colonies, north and south, at the time. Also, after the 
CW when the blacks were free, well over half (closer to three-quarters) 
stayed at least near the plantations they had worked as slaves if not 
always on them, working as sharecroppers. The Freedman's Bureau even 
administered a contract system whereby the former owners contracted for the 
services of the former slaves. Wages and working conditions were clearly 
spelled out.

All I can say is that no free or freed Black person would have worked on a 
plantation in a position that a slave occupied. It was all too easy for 
someone to mistake them for an enslaved person.  Especially if the 
plantation passed into new hands.

I have read a lot about the era of slavery in the U.S. and most free(d) 
Blacks found their own little bit of land, or went to a non-slavery state.  
The other thing is the man said basically that none of them were slaves. 
Under the plantation system, slaves were necessary in order to keep the 
White family from having to do all the work and then have hired hands to 
help.

Worse yet was that at different times laws were enacted that denied any 
free(d) Black person from living within a certain county or state. White 
people did not want free(d) men and women there to encourage the enslaved 
people to run off or band up to demand their freedom.

Also, I used the term free(d) people because as far as I have been able to 
research, there were no actually free Blacks in S.C. at that time. There 
were a few freed people, who had once been slaves but were set free for 
whatever reason. The same would hold true for Alabama, Mississippi and 
mostly likely North Carolina as well. This can be confirmed by searching 
the census records of that time.. They would have included any free(d) 
black people in the census because the taxes were usually higher on their 
land and property. Also, slave owners received at times a reduction in 
their taxes due to having to feed, clothe and shelter their enslaved 
Blacks, and at time the Native Americans they held in the earlier days of 
the colonies.

In basic terms, White people in the states with large slave ownership 
numbers were terrified of any Black person, who would be either free or 
freed, because they were always expecting a slave revolt, several of which 
did occur.

Cheers!

In Braveheart there were other historical inaccuracies. For one, the 
stretcher that William Wallace was on didn't exist at the time. The 
stretcher was not used until the Elizabethan era in the 16th century and it 
wasn't used for torture but confessions.

Queen Isabelle was a girl and unmarried at the time of William Wallace. 
There is no evidence that they ever met.

Edward 2 is seen as an arrogant playboy. In reality most people around him 
considered him fair and lenient however he was not an effective ruler and 
his wife Isabelle had her lover kill him and he was going to force the son 
to abdicate so he could become Roger 1 but the son came with followers and 
had him killed, becoming Edward 3.

The battle of Stirling was seen as an open battlefield. In reality most of 
the battle happened on a bridge and at one point it is said part of the 
bridge collapsed and hundreds of men drowned.

When William Wallace's rebels captured an English fort in the movie, it 
makes it seem as if though he spared their lives. In reality he had them 
all killed and thrown in a ditch and the place is still said to be haunted.

Though Lizard King the Romans initially only regarded the tribes of the 
north as Britons. They listed about 16 or so tribes in Scotland. Those 
south of the Forth (including the Votadini and Selgovae) and those north 
(including the Caledonii). It was only centuries after the coming of the 
Romans that those north of the Forth and completely outwith the Roman 
sphere started being labled Picts. Not necessarily correct to make such a 
division at the coming of the Romans.

It was the Picts who had blue face paint. Not British Celts. The Picts 
occupied what is present day Scotland. Check the Romans and what they wrote 
about the Caledonians, they gave them the name Pict - meaning the painted 
ones. They never called the British Celts anything of the sort. But it was 
the Picts after they had merged with the Scotti tribe from Ireland to fight 
the Anglo Saxons and Vikings. It was at the time when Pictland became 
Scotland by way of christianity. The blue comes from the emblem of St 
Andrew. The reason the Picts adopted it was before battle with the Anglo 
Saxons they thought that god had sent thema sign, which was a St Andrews 
cross shape in the sky. A revelation of it's day if you will.

Though the film doesn't make the blue face up. The novel Braveheart is 
based on the epic Scottish poem. A literary work rather than history. In 
Blind Harry's original Wallace has a vision where his face is painted by a 
sprite. In the later Hamilton version of the 18thC it is the Virgin Mary 
who comes to him in a vision and paints his face. Though the design is 
different. The poem says "crossed with a sapphire" suggesting the Scottish 
flag rather like modern football fans sometimes have.

larger belted plaid as worn by Highlanders though it can only be dated as 
far back as the 1500s. So wrong time for Scots to be dressed like that and

from central and the south of Scotland. The myth is that an Englishman 
called Rawlinson invented the modern kilt for his workers at his Scottish 
factory. Trouble is there are illustrations which show the dress which 
predates his arrival in scotland in the 1730s. More likely that he simply 
thought it was a good design for his workers.

Scottish military dress, but scot did wear a blanket like kilt similar to 
the Greek and Roman dress (which was worn in different styles.) They were 
banned from wearing them by the English, of course until they we once again 
allowed to wear the English style kilt if they joined the British army.

I got 2 big problems with this...
First, you shouldnt confuse "mistakes" with "propaganda", i.e distortion of 
facts to promote an agenda. Your KKK pick is just that, and if you were to 
include that, many early 20th century films made around the world wars in 
the nations in conflict would count. More famous ones would be the 
Riefenstahl films, but nazi Germany was hardly the only producer of such 
propaganda.
Second, if you're going to look at "mistakes" in films regarding history, 
almost every film based on history could provide way more than 10, as most 
films, especially big audience ones, play very loosely with the material: 
often the filmmakers lack knowledge, dont care or want to push their own 
biased views on the era. Political factors then come into the mix, and most 
if not all "historical" films are more or less on the romantisized side of 
things. To me, some of those are downright hurtful to society (Inglorious 
Basterds for instance), while most arent worse than, say, an adaptation of 
Homer's Illias: maybe fun to watch, but certainly not history.

+Squishy Wormy Thank you. Absolutely film makers can (and should) have some 
creative freedom when it comes to depicting history. History often moves at 
a much slower pace than the attention span of the average movie-goer.

That being said, you can clearly see alterations to historical fact that 
contribute nothing to story itself.

Let's take the example from The Patriot for example: the English burning 
down the church. We already know and accept the British as the villains, 
but this act essentially equates British imperial rule over America with 
the Nazis. Unnecessary. There were plot ramifications from the church 
burning - but all of these consequences could have been easily accomplished 
with historical accuracy.

Let's compare that to another Mel Gibson movie: Braveheart. The kilts. They 
are silly, but they do not really alter our perception of anything. They 
simply help us differentiate between the "civilized" but brutal and 
organized British military with the predominantly militia-based Highlanders 
of Scotland. Inaccurate, yes. Ridiculous? A little bit. But it doesn't 
really change anyone's perception of history.

You don't KNOW that William Wallace was 6'8". Feet and inches were not 
standardized until after Napoleon converted the rest of the world to the 
metric system. Part of the reason Napoleon chose the metric system was 
because he could standardize it how he wanted as opposed to each kingdom 
sending in measurements based on their standards and none of them ever 
matched up.

He was reputed to be a tall man, but I doubt he was a power forward on a 
modern basketball team. Also, the William Wallace sword really looks 
16th-17th century. Definitely, the fittings are not dated to the Wallace 
era. Not to mention the true two handed sword such as the Bidenhander or 
Claymore wasn't a product of Wallace's time. There were long swords, but 
consult the Oakeshott typology for examples of what would have been used in 
the late 13th-14th centuries.  Also, the Scottish style clothing that we 
associate with Scotland was part of a Scottish pride movement starting in 
the 17th century and the kilt cannot be reliably dated to before the 16th 
century. The face painting thing was definately silly and way, way pre-time 
period. Most Scottish if depicted properly on film would have been little 
different in appearance from the English of the time to modern unskilled 
eyes. Obviously, though taste and availability in clothing and armour as 
well as regional variations would have been apparent to all who lived 
during the time period, but the difference was much more subtle than 
depicted. I'm glad the movie rekindled Scottish pride, however it set a 
trend in the time that highlighted the unimportance of even pseudo-realism 
in historical movies. Just give us a stereotype and the stuff we expect to 
see in a movie and don't except any responsibility for accuracy.

+speed0spank I don't see how that has been ever mentioned, but I  suppose I 
can explain just how correct your statement is. I'll give you a few facts 
and let you come to your own conclusions, fell free to verify them as you 
please:
1. NSA controls over 70% of internet traffic in the US.
2. Chinese censorship is very specific; it's quite different from let's say 
Iran's. Iran simply censors facebook, Youtube, Twiter and the like. China 
does that as well, but they made their own copies of the pages: Renren, 
Tudou, Weibo.
One of the main reasons they do that is also, that it let's them keep the 
servers in their own hands. With that, they're capable of implementing a 
surveillance on their citizen (not unlike NSA's) on the one hand, and 
they're also protecting their citizens from surveillance of the NSA: they'd 
have such an option if the chinese were using FB (and the like) with serves 
in the US.
3. It isn't at all long ago since USA tried to implement SOPA and PIPA 
which would give the power of censorship to the US corporations far above 
anything China ever did.
4. China has a very specific way of dealing with "politically incorrect" 
content. They usually send a group of their own manipulators to the 
particular website where it's located and attempt to persuade the other 
visitors that the "inappropriate" content is wrong. If possible, they try 
to turn the other public against the poster.That way they very rarely have 
to turn to actual censorship.
5. Chinese central government sometimes uses censorship as a toll to act 
against provincial officalls they dislike: they simply stop censoring 
complaints about them. Then they wait for a while for the public hatred of 
that official to swell up, and then they can remove him with an 
overwhelming public support.
6. The chinese censorship is quite limited in it's capabilities. They don't 
have the ability to overview everything that's written on sites like Baido. 
In fact, they only control the most noticeable, and most viewed content.
7. Ever heard of Google's  and FB sorting algorithms? The way google choses 
and sorts articles and the like in the search results? If google moves 
certain "rebelious" content down in the search results it can assure very 
few people will see it. It's cannot be censorship because the content is 
still available. But it can be rendered ineffective in this way and thus 
have the same effect.
Google even sorts those results for every individual,based on his past 
searches. A fine example is that in the time when the Arab spring started, 
typing "Egypt" into google, some people found news of what's going on there 
in their first results,while others got tourist offers without a single 
mention in the first page of what's going on. Another example is that FB 
sorts you out content it belives you'd disagree with.
In both cases it's not censorship, but the concepts are still 
dangerous;very important informations can be witheld from you by those 
algorithms.  

P.S.  I in no way support any state or corporate control over the free flow 
of information. I'm just trying to prove that things aren't black and 
white: America as land of the free on the one hand and China as a ruthles 
censoring dictator on the other had.

The Americans do often things like in #4 and #2: they show the American 
archiving something, which was in reality archived by someone else. This is 
not only the case in war movies, but also e.g. many inventions which the 
Americans think are American are in reality from somewhere else, a famous 
example is the incandescent lamp, which was not invented by the American 
Thomas Edison, his incandescent lamp is from 1880 and at the first 
incandescent light bulbs where already invented in the early 1800s. The 
first incandescent lamp was built in 1809 by the British Humphrey Davy, who 
proved that a platinum strip glows if you pass electric current through it. 
Even light bulbs which where very similar to the one Edison used (a metal 
filament inside a evacuated glass bulb) where invented long before 1880, 
e.g. 1840 by the British William Grove and Warren de la Rue. Edison 
invented the first commercial successfull version of the incandescent lamp, 
but not the incandescent lamp.﻿

Even though I really enjoyed the film, in Michael Mann's "Public Enemies", 
there are quite a few inaccuracies...

1. Pretty Boy Floyd dies in an apple orchard rather than an open field in 
Ohio...
2. Baby Face Nelson dies at Little Bohemia, Wisconsin rather than on the 
open road during a shootout with FBI agents Samuel Cowley and Herman 
Hollis...
3. Homer van Meter also dies at Little Bohemia rather than in a St. Paul 
alley...
4. Dillinger is involved in the massive escape from the Indiana State Pen 
rather than being in an Ohio jail at the time...
5. Walter Dietrich dies during the prison break when in fact he didn't...
6. Much like Bonnie Parker, there's no concrete evidence that Dillinger 
ever actually killed anyone...
7. 1-6 all happened before the end of the film when Dillinger dies. 
Dillinger died in July 1934. Homer van Meter died in August 1934. Pretty 
Boy Floyd died in October 1934. Baby Face Nelson died in November 1934. ﻿

It's not that simple. You have to bear in mind that the vast majority of 
people living in the British American colonies identified as British. There 
was little sense of an American national identity until after the war had 
ended. Notice that the word "American" never appears in the Declaration of 
Independence. The signatories refer to the British as "Our Brittish (sic) 
bretheren" since they considered THEMSELVES to be British. The 
revolutionary war wasn't a war between the British and the Americans, it 
was a British civil war between two British factions. The aim wasn't even 
to completely break away from Britain, just the King and the British 
parliament. When the King and parliament refused to grant independence, the 
war started. However, it still wasn't that clean cut. The American colonies 
weren't in great financial shape, most of the wealth lay with slave and 
plantation owners, who were also the main pro-independence faction. Why? 
Because they stood to gain from not paying tax to the British government 
when it was requested as payment towards the cost of defending the 
colonies. They also stood to gain by becoming independent as the British 
government were increasingly pushing for the abolition of slavery in the 
colonies. The British government weren't exactly brilliant to the 
colonists, but it wasn't a case of Americans vs the British, it was wealthy 
British colonists vs the British government. It should also be noted that 
few of the wealthy who stood to gain from independence actually fought in 
the war, they could afford to pay other people to fight for them. The 
portrayal in the film is acceptable since it's a work of fiction for 
entertainment with a historical background. Its historical accuracy is 
abysmal, however.

+Zexus995 I agree to an extent, but this very much down to the reasoning 
behind changing history within the stories framework.

For instance, in the Film Pearl Harbor it shows US fighters getting off of 
the ground to fight the Japanese during the attack, this was done because 
the main characters in the film where pilots, despite no US fighters 
getting airborne during the actual event (I think.) This I do not find to 
be an issue as it is just injecting some action into that horrific piece of 
shit 'Merican circle jerk bonanza.

On the other hand, showing the Japanese attacking a hospital full of 
civilians during the attack on Pearl Harbor, something the didn't do, is 
not on. It doesn't add to the story, it portrays them in a negative fashion 
for an act they never did. What I found more annoying in this film is that 
during the part on the Doolittle raid it decides not to show the Americans 
bombing civilians... Or in other words, that film would have been a great 
propaganda piece during the war. 
It's not even like the Japanese had a clean slate, but no, don't show them 
committing war crimes in China, Burma or Singapore, show a fictional attack 
on US civilians. 
/rantover.

+Zexus995
History is not meant to teach us. History is just history. things that have 
happened. what we decide to do with it is entirely up to us.

What you want isnt really movies that show us what actually happened, 
because that wouldn't make a good story. What you want is just "more 
correct facts" about big things like battles and so on. But i make the case 
that the most important thing is that the story is entertaining, and if 
history has to be rewritten for that, it doesnt matter. For example. In 
Inglorious Basterds, Hitler was gunned down in a theater. It was a nice 
twist to the movie and i wasn't outraged that they changed history.

History is meant to teach us. We are meant to learn from our personal 
pasts, and from our ancestors pasts. Its ok to make History into 
Entertainment such as a movie. If so, at least what happened on those 
events should be portrayed with the right facts, rather than have false 
ideas and facts flow around.
[ Truth > Entertainment ]
